@DG I'm sick of the aggressive "Who decided" argument the NRA and the gun-obsessed keep throwing out. We live in a community, which means we have tacitly agreed to a social contract whereby we surrender some individual rights and freedoms in exchange for protection of those remaining. We vote. That's how "we decide" -- "we the people."

Who decided that you may own as powerful a weapon and as much ammunition as you want, whether you have been tested for skill with that weapon or for the psychological stability to use it sanely ("Road rage" is not mental illness, nor is "recent job loss" or "impending divorce" or a host of other things that have driven people to murder with firearms.)

Who decided you don't have to be relicensed regularly, or that you may own a weapon that isn't in a permanent registry and therefore cannot be traced if stolen or illegally sold? Your car comes with a VIN, it must be registered, and any purchase or sale must also be recorded with a government agency. You must buy liability insurance for your car. Why should it be different with firearms?

As for your comment, "A 10-round limit would not have prevented loss of life in the horrible Newtown situation. But it sure does make people feel good about their need to "do something," I am speechless. Didn't you claim that 10 or 15 rounds would make a difference in protecting YOUR family?

Living in a community means we balance the needs and desires of individuals with those of the community.

Do you mean multiple NEW coal-fired power plants going on every week in the US? This isn't so, almost no new coal-fired plants are being built. New plants in the US are going to natural gas because it is cheap and clean, and older plants are starting to retrofit to burn it.

New coal-fired plants are still being built at high rates in China, and rather distressingly Europe is seeing a return to coal-fired plants as nuclear plants are being shut down post Chernobyl, post Fukushima.

A critical first step is to stop exporting coal -- the US needs to stop, we need to convince Australia, Indonesia, Russia and South Africa to stop too. It is CRAZY for America to ship coal to China, so they can use it to destroy our economy and the planet.

These plants could be avoided, and may be converted to natural gas in the future, as "fracking" production techniques become widely used. China in particular is thought to have large shale-gas potential.

If the best technology generating plants are used (combined cycle plants) a new natural-gas power plant can have about 1/3 the CO2 emission per watt of a typical older technology coal-fired plant. This very large reduction comes from the combination of the lower carbon content of methane and the very high efficiency of the combined-cycle plant (which does have higher capital cost).

All this being said, yes of course it will take major international agreements and all nations will need to take serious steps to reduce CO2 emissions.

I take your point and partially agree with you, but I wouldn't say that a intelligent consensus hasn't been reached by those Americans among us who live in the year 2013.

The long run up to the fiscal cliff is finally over.

Now, it’s time for President Obama to address an even more serious cliff: the climate change cliff — the one we’re fast approaching as the amount of global-warming pollution in our atmosphere continues to rise.

President Obama needs to take bold and decisive action to help protect our nation against climate change’s ravages.

Climate change is the great challenge of our time.

Three things can be done by President Obama on his own, without needing the dysfunctional Congress to act:

First, elevate the issue of climate disruption and climate solutions in the public discourse. Why? Because the president has to rally public support for the bold steps he must take to address climate change and to make sure those steps aren’t undone by Congress.

Second, use the EPA’s existing authority under the Clean Air Act to limit global-warming pollution from existing power plants. Currently, America’s fossil-fuel-fired power plants produce a full 40% of our global warming pollution, making them by far the largest source. EPA can set standards that will achieve big reductions at low cost.

Third, the last thing we need to burn is high-carbon fuel, like tar sands. President Obama should reject the Keystone XL pipeline, which would transport a huge amount of tar sands across the highly sensitive aquifers that supply much of the water for the agricultural plains, and will endanger our health and safety.

Martha, I agree. My daughter was born in the UK and the guidelines there said to have no more than 1-2 drinks, once or twice per week. I abstained completely for the first trimester, then had about 1 glass of wine per week for the rest of my pregnancy. Looking back I feel more guilty about the amount of caffeine free diet coke and McDonald's I consumed during pregnancy (not my normal diet, but those were my pregnancy cravings). Aside from MD's valid observation that no nearby planet could survive ...

... if you know of any mechanism by which a G star with billions of years of hydrogen fuel remaining could go supernova any time in near future (by which I mean, the nest few millions years), I encourage you to publish it: there should be a Nobel prize in it for you!

1) Our sun is a yellow dwarf and lacks the mass necessary to initiate a nova, let alone a supernova.

2) Our sun is only about halfway through its fusion fuel. It's got another few billion years to go before it starts swelling up.

3) A supernova is not a temporary crisis. A supernova that happens within 50 light-years of Earth will be a PERMANENT crisis, as in the atmosphere will be blown away by the shock wave and all life fried with the barrage of cosmic rays. It's not a cooling event. It's an event with so much energy that it can lead to fusion of elements heavier than iron, which is something a star cannot do on its own.

Speaking as a professional astronomer, the Sun cannot "go supernova". It has far too little mass to do that.

The Sun will gradually heat up over the next 4.5 billion years or so before it becomes a red giant and eats the Earth. Ultimately it will become a white dwarf.

I'm guessing that MD in NYC is correct that you may have confused "supernova" with some other phenomenon.

To Sam: here is a fact you should consider: Spending has become an issue because some nut cases think that severely cutting spending is the only way to reduce the debt. The debt, added to yearly by the deficit, is the problem. Not the spending. In order to decrease the debt, one needs to understand how it got as high as it did. By the end of this year we will have ended the two wars that added trillions to the debt. Therefore, the defense budget needs to go back to pre-war levels. The economy needs to be revived, resulting in more tax revenues and fewer expenditures in the form of unemployment benefits and Medicaid/SNAP payments. All the Bush tax cuts need to eventually end. Cutting any other programs is unnecessary as they had no role in creating the debt.

The tax rates and spending levels in 2000 were in balance. That is were we need to go.

Then we can think about a carbon tax.

@Christine

It's really all scary. Anything, at this point, that might curtail the diminished purchasing power, especially gas, might help another slowdown of the economy. That is why, among other reasons, we need to get people working again before we attempt to reduce the debt. It doesn't mean we shouldn't make things more efficient or continue to waste wherever we do, but to start cutting now would be a huge mistake.

@Sam I wasn't proposing to switch only to wind but to make more of an investment in wind farms wherever it makes the most sense. The more we do, the better off we are.

As for Tom not calling for austerity... Anytime anyone talks about the "debt" you have to wonder, especially after the advent of the Fix The Debt group.

The only thing carbon-related that the GOP has allowed is the continuation of Big Oil's subsidies. Everything else is a no-go. Sure, there should be a carbon tax. In part, it could pay for lots of things, including accelerated production of wind power and research into alternative methods of fuel. For as long as the GOP has the upper hand in the House, however, I can't see that happening.

As for the debt, as others have pointed out, the last thing we should do right now is reverse course. We need to grow the economy and get the millions who are still unemployed working, shopping, and paying their taxes first. Once we're back at full employment, then it will be time to accelerate the repayment schedule. The difference between this Great Recession and the current deficit and the budget deficit under Clinton is the same as night and day.
